review:
[b]extremely conditional recommendation![/b]

if you want something that has references to adventure time and some fun nods towards things finn and jake can do in canon, this game probably does that for you. it's kind of dated with regard to how it controls, but it's more or less an adventure time game, and there's clearly a bit of love in it. 

if you're used to the quality of life games tend to give you these days, though, i DO NOT recommend it. i could not stop being annoyed while playing this because i found the controls clunky and the powers confusingly limited. if there's one thing that's going to take me out of an adventure time experience, it's finn not being able to jump over a 2 foot gap. 

if you' just want adventure time games that you can kind of turn your brain off during, this game is fine; otherwise, i'd probably recommend pirates of the enchiridion.

review:
This is a pretty simple dungeon crawler. Reminds me a little of Toejam and Earl with the level design, but with zelda-like combat. You can press a button to switch between Finn & Jake.

I'm personally a fan of Adventure Time, but you don't really need to watch the show to play this. The plot is barely there. Finn & Jake go to play with BMO like they always do but instead get sucked into the video game and then have to fight through 4 worlds of floating islands to escape. (Grass, Ice, Fire, and Death). There is a lot of power up scrolls you can find that give you temporary abilities, but beware of the reshuffle, which changes all the powers on all your scrolls and you have to blindly figure out which is which again. My suggestion is when you find Princess Bubblegum for the first time, have her identify all your scrolls until you find Reshuffle, make note of it, and NEVER TOUCH IT AT ALL. That way you know what power ups you have at all times.

There is no zone travel a-la mario, but you can easily go back to the previous world by jumping off the edge of your current world, which is what made me think of Toejam & Earl.

EDIT: I think at some point they added cloud saves. I was near the end when my hard drive crashed and thankfully I didn't lose my save this time.

review:
Canonically Takes place around Season 5

‚óòThe combat is extremely basic and revolves around a light attack and a heavy attack, which can be coordinated to perform combos. You can play as Finn or Jake who functionally are the same with the exception of a defensive move. Finn has a roll and for Jake has a shield block. 

‚óòThe game gives you spendable powers that come in the form of temporary companions (e.g. NEPTR), movement bonuses (e.g. stretchy jake) and general stat improvement (e.g. Jake Suit). All powers are generally discovered within the first island, which leads to later game being much blander as all powers can be discovered extremely early.

‚óòThe enemy variation is fairly low. Although each area has a handful of unique enemies as well as bosses. 

‚óòPersonally, i feel like the levels are too large as it's too easy to find every power and reach max level before the end. There's not enough discoverable content to justify the amount of area that is in the game. This may cause you to burn out towards the end of the game.

review: First, the only reason I bought this is because I'm a huge Adventure Time fan. If you are a fan of the show, you might find some enjoyment out of this game. If you aren't a fan of Adventure Time, then you might want to pass on this, seeing how it only took around 10 hrs to beat entirely. The graphics are good, the game play is smooth, no crashes or stability issues, solid controller support. However, it is extremely repetative to the point of becoming very boring, very fast. You fight the same monsters over and over, I maxed out my level by the third area, and a large portion of the Enchiridion pages are pretty useless through out much of the game (Shadowcery and Spit Bubbles being the most useless). By the end I had collected so many Enchiridion pages that I beat down Death with an astonishing 200 hit combo (all in the Jake Suit) and not a single life lost. Also, the only characters that actually have speaking parts are Finn and Jake, and BMO (though to a much lesser degree). The cut scenes were also very disappointing, with weak, hastily slapped together dialogue, if any dialogue at all (none of the bosses do anything other than make a digitized sounding roar, no speaking parts :(. Honestly,  I thought they could have done much better with an Adventure Time game rather than rehash a premise used twice in the cartoon series already. I just felt like they could have made something more like an RPG similar to Super Mario - Legend of the Silver Stars. Instead you end up with a very mediocre, highly predictable beat em' up game which has almost no replay value. This is the type of game I would let my 6 year old nephew play since it is relatively inoffensive and not bloody or excessively violent.

review:
I have to say, as a huge Adventure Time fan, I was completely and utterly disappointed by this game, I feel like it's very basic and the game play is more annoying as opposed to actually playing a fun, cute and humorous arcade type of platform game, it's almost like they didn't do any effort with this game and were only keen to make money since they knew so many people would be interested in an Adventure Time game on Steam.

Expect a repetitive, boring and dull game. You will be bored to death within the first 15 minutes and it might even make you hesitant to watch Adventure Time for a while just because of how poorly this game was at capturing the Adventure Time franchise.

I really wish they would would have added more characters like Lumpy Space Princess and some random penguins just for the heck of it, I mean, what is Adventure Time without Lumpy Space Princess? It feels empty, cheap and boring. Prepare to feel uninspired and annoyed for paying so much for a game that is also free, if you're gonna make people pay for a free game, at least have the decency to add some cute and fun features and give the game a bigger variety of maps and everything else for that matter.

If I were you, rather save your money for something that will actually be enjoyable because I am completely saddened at this game that should have been a PlayStation 2 game, instead.

The game is cute, but the controls are atrocious.
I can attack while moving up, down, left, right, and diagonally up-right,
but I can't attack diagonally up-left, down-left, or down-right.
Why can't I attack in 3 of the 8 directions?
I don't even understand how that could even be possible to mess up.
Also, the button setup is bad.
Space is attack/action, the arrows are movement, ctrl is power attack, 
shift is roll, z is switch character, x is open book.
The buttons are also not changable.

Also, when I met Choose Goose he said,
"i've got something for you, a metal shoe"
He had no metal sheos.

Also, since when did Finn use magic?
It's like, all this game is,
bad combat, and magic book pages.

And what's with the leveling system?
Is my health goeing up? I can't tell.

I love adventure time, but this game is bad.

Why can't anyone just make an action adventure rpg, adventure time game.
That would work best for the series.
Something like the old Zelda games, or even a side scrolling metroidvania type games.

I also hate how steam dosn't have a spell checker or auto correct.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055003042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5226, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1709756204}
review:
(Scroll to the bottom for pros and cons)

What time is it? Adventure Time! That's right, you get to play as both Finn and Jake in this fully 3D game while defeating enemies and grabbing treasure and unleashing different kinds of powers.

Hmmm, alright, where to begin...I guess with the good sides. The game offers a lot of different actions to do, not just a single attack, albeit you will be using just two keys to attack. But the combos with the default weapons can be fun to execute as well as all the Enchiridion pages as they offer lots of different styles to attack with. The game is relatively short and can be passed in one day in some hours, but even so, it really drags you in and is a decent way of killing time. The levels are also big so you can explore very long if you wish to collect everything along the way.

So, attack variance is the best feature of the game as far as I can tell. The graphics aren't too bad either but obviously they aimed at a simple, cartoonish style which looks great and is clear, and, most importantly, works. And the music...most of the tracks heard ingame are straight from the show and extended. It's a very nice touch. And lastly, the way in which the levels are is quite clever, islands. They are warped around a sphere shape to create an illusion of a planet, sort of. It works and it stays simple.

---

However, that's it for the good sides unfortunately. Like mentioned above, the game is relatively short, and that is biggest of the cons. Just 4 different locations with a few levels each. The version on Cartoon Network has 7 different locations. I wonder why some of them were scrapped. But yeah, could be longer...I guess this game would do great as a speedrun game, but...eh. I know there isn't much of a story, but it's kinda forced to have some sense as to why the game exists in the first place. There also aren't a lot of cutscenes, only ones appearing in the beginning of the game and in-between the locations. But that's understandable as the game isn't sandbox so you just complete the levels.

Then next, the soundtrack will get kinda annoying and unbearable at points since some tracks are fast tempo or 8-bit. You can always mute, but then it would eat some of the atmosphere, meaning you would be listening to sound effects only. Thankfully not all tracks are like that. Also, while the levels are quite clever and offer some sort of variance, it's not enough. Sure, all levels are different and you have 4 different locations but the gameplay stays the same. Just hack and slashing your way through while collecting things and perhaps completing quests. But that's it. It's a very simple game. And then...bugs and glitches. The game has a big number of them, although you might not even run into them. But having spent enough time in the game to nearly master the mechanics and run through the game quickly, I've ran into a few. Bugs include attack buttons being greyed out and disabled (only way to attack is using the pages, and the problem would persist until next level. I had to restart the game to fix it), characters disappearing, either the player or bosses, etc. Some bugs can really hurt the gameplay, and for glitches there are some funny ones, e.g. seeing a doppelg√§nger of Finn or Jake or seeing the Fire enemies spawning away once you kill them.

---

A few notes: Some things that really caught my attention include:

Jake's Stilts power. It's very tricky to use when reaching small islands. Now I know you have to think twice before using a power-up to reach islands, but I've fallen numerous times thanks to not quite making it on the other side. This isn't a bug or a glitch however, it's a part of the difficulty but can be hard to notice sometimes. 

Dying: While it isn't a consequence since you can have plenty of lives, it does take a big chunk out of your treasure amount. You will get healed, but at the cost of (obviously) one life and hefty loot. Why pay lots of money for health when you can grab food for free or buy it or get healed for only 100 gold from the doctor...just saying, it's acceptable. It's like the same way how you lose all your rings in Sonic games, you need to watch it. Speaking of health...

Health: You'll notice that health is actually shared between Finn and Jake, so you can't switch the character to regain health. This does make sense however when talking about difficulty and the fact you wouldn't leave a dead friend behind as you would go on (lol)

-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-

Pros and cons:

+ 3 difficulties to pick from to suit every player type: beginner, casual or experienced
+ Lots of different power-ups and enemies, gives some freedom over gameplay style
+ Can run through levels quickly without the need to go everywhere
+ Finn and Jake's official voice actors have done plenty of lines
+ Play as Finn or Jake, both have their good and bad sides.
+ Clever level design, plenty to explore
+ The soundtrack is catchy
+ Gameplay mechanics
+ Graphics look nice

- Experience gained is miniscule when defeating enemies later on. Makes you think why you bother.
- While there is variety in attacking, it will still be spamming the attack button(s) pretty much.
- Fixed camera (debatable, but I feel like a self-controlled camera would've been cool)
- Has no proper cutscenes or backstory. It's all about the gameplay itself.
- Pointless features, e.g. floaties. You only use them in a few levels.
- Bosses have no lines, nor do the enemies. Only Finn and Jake.
- No hub world to visit previous worlds (or levels more quickly).
- Could have more achievements for those who like to get 'em.
- Lots to explore but not really worth it.
- Full of bugs and glitches
- Gets repetitive
- Too short.

Summary: 50/50. If you are a fan of Adventure Time or hack n slash games, consider grabbing the game. Don't get your hopes up too high though. While the game has a lot of flaws it's playable and will keep you occupied at least during the first time you beat the game. Just rest assured you will have to play a lot without being really rewarded with anything, save for a few cutscenes, credits and a happy feeling.

A few last words...well, left a bad taste in my mouth because of the bugs and lack of cutscenes/cinematics. Also the length of the game...if it was a lot longer it'd be very cool. The game had a lot of potential but it wasn't used to its full extent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014811902', 'num_games_owned': 367, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1428766738}
review:
[h1] Context [/h1]
I'm a huge Adventure Time fan, but generally not into this sort of game.

[h1] The Good [/h1]
They have the voice actors from the show which is nice. The art style is nice (but unfortunately let down by the graphical fidelity). It runs fine too. That's about it.

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
Ignoring the fact that this used to be a free browser game (http://www.cartoonnetwork.com.au/games/adventure_time/epic-quest/) and hasn't changed drastically since that iteration, this game is boring, repetitive, lazy and cheap. It looks like crap, controls like crap, feels like crap and sounds like crap. This game sort of feels like it was made by people who do really care about the show, and wanted to make something that does it justice, but there simply wasn't enough money or talent to do so.

[h1] Visuals [/h1]
While the art style is good, the graphical quality is terrible and there are "jaggies" everywhere you look. Each stage has a single, static, unfathomably low resolution backdrop. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=423231818 The levels from each world look very similar, and there are not many landmarks to help you remember where you are. This isn't helped by the lack of a mini-map.

[h1] Control [/h1]
The controls are fairly responsive, but the animations don't flow well into each other, which along with other things, results in really bad game-feel. Running around and fighting does not feel fun. I find myself actively avoiding enemies just because they simply aren't fun to kill. The camera nauseatingly jerking back and forth as you change directions, and vibrating slightly when you run in diagonals does not help the cause. Nothing in this game feels fun; the only enjoyment you get comes from completing tasks and advancing through the stages.

[h1] Sound [/h1]
The sound design was put together in an obvious rush. Sound effects cut abruptly in and out, play at seemingly random volumes and sound like they were pulled straight from a stock library with little to no afterthought. Although the voice actors do a decent job, the dialogue during cutscenes is riddled with pops and clicks. The music is clearly trying to simulate the style of the cartoon, with beeps, boops, clicks and melodies played in unprocessed analogue synths. The sentiment is nice, but it falls short, sometimes sounding less Adventure Time-esque and more midi file-esque.


[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
The combat isn't fun enough, and the enemies not versatile enough to make up for how mind-numbingly repetitive this game is. Once you've played the first 3 levels, you've experienced most of what you're going to get out of the rest of the game.

[h1] This game isn't worth your time, or your money. [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198009970011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1428425708}
review:
I wouldn't even recommend this to the hardcore AT fan.

- The levels are laughably tedious, drawn out and each a reskinned version of the one before. The map doesn't allow you to look at the whole stage.

- Combat is weak, dodging out of enemies vastly telegraphed moves makes it boring after the first stage, combined with few varations. (Tree Witch in the Fire Kingdom, come on...)

- Upgrades are based on refrences from the show, and that's about it. Some are just plain hard aimed for no reason and deal no real damage (looking at you Ice Shuriken, seriously I'm better off with Light attacks), some are powerful but are also hard to aim, and some are just much, much better than the others but takes away what little effort this skilless game already had. 

The last of the upgrades are just a big 'you hoarded some good upgrades to make the last fight quick? Well fuck you, player'. Thanks guys, as if your game wasn't alread√Ω boring me to tears. Small appreciation in being able to play as Fiona and Cake, but that should have been an unlockable bonus, same with other characters. 

- No boss dialogues. (understandable given the ending, but still wth?)

- Music is repitive and boring.

+ Art is decent, original VA, but that's about it.

So what made me finish this game? Well I love AT, and I just wanted a good ending for my efforts of playing this pile of 'the stuff', but even that they denied me. I got a pat on the back and the ridiculous notion that I should play it again.

2/10

Thanks, but no thanks!

review:
What time is it? It's review time. I'll get right down to it: this game sucks. At first you think it's going to be fun playing an exploration game in the vein of Adventure Time, but it's anything but fun. The "look for stuff and backtrack" design of gameplay is just tiresome by the 2nd world map, and by the 3rd, you just want it to be over and done with. The first Toe Jam & Earl game for the Sega Genesis had a similar feel and look, but was loads more fun.

Not very challenging since you can easily avoid most enemies. Also disappointing that you can only level up to level 15, and as a result, you don't feel very powerful when defeating enemies. 

The last boss is awkward to fight since I beat him by chipping his healthy away very slowly and healing constantly - NOT good game design.

Oh well, I know better. I won't be playing this again or any Adventure Time games anytime soon until they make the game mechanics fun and addicting.

review:
This is a bit of a wonky game, but in a fun way. The game is set like diablo's dungeon crawl system, but your focus is to make it to the end of the stage (wherever that may be) with all of the relics on the stage. There is no minimap, so it gets a bit confusing at times. At the end of each world, there is a boss which relates to the show, and the area that you just completed which usually isn't that hard to fight.

If you watch the show as much as I do, you'll appreciate the powerups, as they all relate to funny/cool things from the episodes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001794713', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 427, 'playtime_forever': 454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 454, 'last_played': 1417370276}
review:
It just blows my mind how such an imaginary show can produce a dull boring grindfest game with no story......

Pros:

+ many power ups
+ you can level up and then get better weapons
+ Nvidia 3D TV Play looks great
+ controller support with good default mapping

Cons:

- its a monotone button masher grindfest......pretty boring to say the least
- every level feels the same, there is no variation except for a paint job
- only 3 combos are available in the entire game! (and you are likely to spam one of these)
- too few enemy types, that are just being reskinned
- you can walk trough the whole game, without hitting one single enemy
- they stretch the game time with unnecessary fetch quests, kill x, open x chests, get x pages.....
- the story is so dull and boring, especially for Adventure Time, I was kinda shocked
- you can control Jake and Finn, but it doesnt seem to change things up enough, you can play just one of them the entire time (Jake does a little bit more damage, likely everybody played with him)
- though there are 2 characters simultaneously on the screen, there is no coop mode! NO COOP MODE!
- gamplay is tireing fast, you have no courage to play it through - nothing is rewarding or cool
- Adventure Time paint job, it feels tacked on, nothing is really like in the show and feels incredibly lifeless
- the power ups are ok, but a lot are just not useful, like the spitbubbles or Lady Rainicorn
- extremely easy difficulty even on hardest setting, I got bored to death

author: {'steamid': '76561198037586730', 'num_games_owned': 792, 'num_reviews': 413, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 456, 'last_played': 1410433255}
review:
While it's called Adventure Time, this game doesn't really benefit from having AT title.

First off, if you're buying this game because it is an adventure time game, you're not buying it for the right reason. It has characters from adventure time, and that's about it. The story isn't gone into too deeply. You find yourself thrust into a videogame world. You try to find bmo. All explained in the opening sequence that's pretty much it.

The main premise of a world is 6 levels and a boss. You hack and slash (kind of button mashy at times) through enemies, collecting various enchiridion pages that offer powers. It's worth mentioning that the game will be very easy unless played on the harder difficulty setting. The pages themselves are plentiful, so you can almost never run out.

I feel that this game might have benefited more from a rogue-like procedural generation level structure, rather than having fixed levels. It would have made it more challenging, and it would have given the game a lot of replay value. As it is, the static levels don't do the game any favours.

This game can be played with both controller or a K&M setup. The controls cannot be customized through the menu, but thre are a few "presets" to choose from. Peronally, I found using a controller to be the more logical way to play this, as there are not many keys to be used.

Thr graphics are very good during gameplay, but when you are shown close-ups during cutscenes, the models look very odd. The cutscenes might have benefited from being animated and pre-rendered. There is a fair amont of variance throughout each of the worlds, which is good.

The voice acting in this is limited to that of finn & jakes's cutscenes and some BMO is thrown in there too. Oddly, none of the bosses were given voice acting, despite the fact that they speak in the show. I found this rather odd. The background music for this game is very good. It has a sort of retro gaming feel to it, but it's not fully 8-bit in style.

There are some bugs in this game, but none I found to be game breaking in any way. The game devs included a "return to start" option in the menu, which helps if you get stuck on a floating island in the middle of nowhere. Fun fact: You can actually use this option at any time, even if it is "greyed out".

In short, don't buy this game just because the adventure time label is slapped on it. It is a fun game for a single playthrough, but beyond that it has no replay value, as far as i'm concerned. If you're a fan of roguelikes you probably won't be interested, but it might appeal more to people who want to get in to roguelikes, as this game is about half way there already, if a bit button mashy at times.

review:
I hate to give a bad review, but I really do not recommend this game. Here's why. 

It feels like this game was only half finished before it was released. The gameplay is very stale and repetitive. 
I don't mind the simplicity, but there is an extreme lack of creativity. The trailer makes this game look like there is a lot more to it. The game is even called "Epic Quest", leading you to believe that you're in for a good adventure game. But all of the "quests" are just tedious levels of fighting the same monsters over and over. 

The dialogue is terrbile for Finn and Jake, and the other characters don't even speak at all. The story is really boring and will make you feel that the entire game is pointless; ending off with Finn and Jake saying "Let's Play Again". I had this game 100% complete in 6 hours, (which most of you could probably do faster) and I never will "Play Again".

Luckily I purchased this game when it was on sale. $9.99 is a bit too pricey for this game.

review:
What time is it?? HONESTY TIME!
7/10
Recommended for fans of AT

This game, is as others may have already said, is Toejam and Earl but with an AT skin. For those of you not familiar with Toejam and Earl, it's this game but with aliens and colorful presents instead of Finn, Jake and Enchiridion pages. 

Gameplay itself is a blast and beating up all the AT villains is just fun and partly crazy, freaking enchiridion pages out the ying yang lets you use whatever you want whenever. You think you've had all the fun then PARTY GOD shows up and you go maraud some more. 

As stated above this is honesty time. While the game is a lot of fun, its only a lot of fun till the end of third world, where everything caps out pretty much. By then you'll have long since found all the enchiridion pages and have probably maxed out the level and gotten all the weapons. This leaves it feeling a bit wanting, as the next seven levels in world five may simply be glazed over as the only reason for fighting enemies is to level up or get coins. Not needing anything else really you're free to scamper by every enemy as they really dont chase you. 

In short, had this game ended with beating up Fire King, it would be well rounded and just plain tons of fun, which it still is.
I enjoyed it myself and I hope more come out like it, just a little more fine tuned.

I don't really know the adventure game franchise - I noticed they have a lot of fans - so I can only comment on the gameplay itself and my experience from an independent angle.

I powergamed the first five levels after which the game became already really repetative so I couldn't go on anymore. Sure there'll be some new worlds a few levels ahead but I couldn't bother. Reviews called it a kid's Diablo but even compared to D3 it is really shallow with a good lot of backtracking and lacking a sense of progression, plot or going anywhere. Even though ARPGs are seldom plot-heavy the slow gameplay and lack of variation killed it fast for me. 
While not being broken or glaringly bad there's just nothing remarkable about it if you're a seasoned player who played the top 75% games of the last two decades.

Even if you are a die-hard fan or just play an hour per week I believe there are dozens of better games you could waste your time on. For playing with kids I'd rather recommend Lego.

review:
[b]This is a long review so if you just want a brief summary of why I recommend this game skip to [u]Results[/u] and read from there.[/b]

NGD Studios does a great job bringing Adventure Time to the video game world with this epic hack ‚Äòn slash adventure. Adventure Time: Finn and Jake‚Äôs Epic Quest is a fantastic game that mixes the great elements from RPGs with the awesome level schemes of ToeJam & Earl.

[b]Story:[/b]
Adventure Time: Finn and Jake‚Äôs Epic Quest takes you out of the Land of Ooo and throws you into a new world that splits Ooo into floating islands. You play as Finn and Jake as they find themselves in a video game, which they use to explain all the weird elements. BMO has gone missing and it‚Äôs up to you to bring him back, but where is he? As you progress through the game you receive clues that help you find your lost comrade. In order to solve the mystery you must find artifacts scattered throughout the worlds, and eventually you will find the key.

[b]Campaign:[/b]
The campaign is split across four worlds, which you can either run through quickly or if you take your time exploring every corner. Each world has six levels and a boss, which you must use different tactics to defeat. The first world is the Witch‚Äôs Garden (if you remember the show this is where Jake loses his powers for an episode because he stole a donut), Ice Kingdom, Fire Kingdom, and Land of the Dead. The levels have various minions which are all from the show, and you will fight bosses that are all characters who Finn and Jake got into scruffs with. 

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
The game takes elements from hack ‚Äòn slash titles and mixes it with that of ToeJam & Earl. In fact this game is almost exactly like Toe Jam and Earl except you can attack enemies. You find pages of the Enchiridion which you can use producing some sort of result either positive or negative. You can pay Princess Bubblegum to identify the pages, which if you ever find again it will remain identified (unless you use a page randomizer). Your character has a maximum level of 15, and every three levels you gain a new weapon. The weapons make your character stronger and grant them with special abilities. Jake is the powerhouse and Finn is for speed. As you progress throughout the game you will find keys which you can use to unlock chests, and you must search for artifacts. Similar to ToeJam & Earl you will be informed which levels artifacts are on so you don‚Äôt need to search every level. You can fall of the edges of the world which allows you to return to previous levels meaning you can go backwards in the campaign. Although unlike ToeJam & Earl you can only fall one level at a time, and the campaign seems to save the previous levels enemies so if you go back the levels are empty. The Enchiridion offers about thirty pages: two have negative results, three help you get across gorges, two of them give money, one of them gives health items, and the rest provide you with some sort of buff. Overall there are not too many pages, but you will enjoy them if you use them.

[b]Hints:[/b][spoiler]
> I found myself searching every nook and cranny of each level, but once you hit level 15 there is no point in hanging around. 
>Levels with artifacts tell you that they have artifacts, so you don‚Äôt need to search every level.
>Don‚Äôt use any pages until you‚Äôve had princess bubblegum examine them (because if you select the page randomizer you can lose really good pages).
>I beat the game on hard and I played the entire game only using the occasional food page. If I were playing this game again I would use as many pages as possible because the game is incredibly easy either way.
>The keys pass through the levels, so if you have some keys on one level you can bring them to the next one.
>If you need to get off in a hurry just jump off the edge of the world, it saves the game for you and puts you at the end of the previous level.[/spoiler]

[b]Results:[/b]
Adventure Time: Finn and Jake‚Äôs Epic Quest is a brilliant game that brings together elements of traditional Hack ‚Äòn Slash and combines it with the greatness of ToeJam & Earl. I would not be amazed if the developers made this as a tribute to ToeJam & Earl. The game has four different bosses, loads of different enemies, crazy amounts of Enchiridion pages that give you special abilities, 24 levels (28 if you include boss fights), and quests that keep you going. If you like adventure games, RPGs, and Hack ‚Äòn Slash this is the game for you. 

Pros:
+Long campaign with 28 total levels, including boss fights.
+Loads of Enchiridion pages which allow you to essentially cast special spells.
+Fifteen levels, which allow you to become stronger.
+A funny story that brings Adventure Time to life.
+Great voice acting and awesome music.
+Four crazy boss fights that require you to use various tactics and strategies.
+Two different characters which you can switch through using different abilities. 
+Decent graphics

Cons:
-The game can get rather repetitive; you definitely will want to take a break from it every now and then.
-When you fall off a level it puts you right at the end of the previous level. 
-The audio volume settings are in the same page as the graphics settings (if you change the audio volume it also reapplies the graphic settings). 
-There could be more Enchiridion pages, the book seems kind of bland at times and most of the pages seem to accomplish the same thing.
-There isn‚Äôt that much voice acting involved, there is very little conversation between any of the characters.
-Even on hard this game is ridiculously easy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031791338', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 456, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1544896741}
review:
Un gran juego si eres fan de la serie de Hora de aventuras, a mi me ha gustado mucho y lo he disfrutado de principio a fin.

De todas formas voy a destacar algunos puntos que he ido sacando en conclusi√≥n, por si estais planteandoos comprar este maravilloso juego:

PROS:
-Es fiel a la serie como el solo, las voces (aunque algunos sean mudos), los personajes, y la musiquilla (aunque hay quien dice que es repetiva), que recuerda a varios episodios de la serie.
-Los niveles son completos, largos y algunos con misiones que te haran dar vueltas para rebuscar cosas por el nivel (o monstruos que matar).
-El juego es bastante facil de jugar, apenas tardaras 10 minutos en comprender todos los controles del juego y los combos posibles.
-Hay un monton de objetos utilizables en el juego, hechizos de un solo uso que casi nunca agotas (entre ellos puedes invocar a ROLFtas, el robot lanza tartas, que no tiene desperdicio :P), aportan diversion extra.
-Si vas intentando resolver todos las misiones, y todos los logros, seguramente te dure 10 horas de entretenimiento.
-Cada monstruo tiene su forma de ser derrotado, algunos de forma facil, otros buscandole el punto debil o arreandoles muy fuerte, otros separandote y acercandote, etc.. aun asi no te sera muy dificil cogerles el truco.
-No resulta nada violento a pesar de la ensalada de panes que reparten Finn & Jake.

CONTRAS:
-Esta solamente en ingles :(, (aunque si conoces la serie les entenderas a la primera).
-Es un juego sencillo, parece orientado para ni√±os, no supone dificultad alguna sacarte todos los logros o llegar al maximo nivel; apenas habia empezado el nivel 4 (o mundo 4) y ya tenia el nivel maximo.
-No puedo saltar.... muy chulos los movimientos de los protas.. pero que para saltar de un borde cercano (o muy cercano) a otro tenga que usar un pergamino a la fuerza , es un poco triste, aunque admito que pergaminos no faltan y aportan diversi√≥n extra, no hubiera ido mal que hubiera un boton para saltar sin depender de nada m√°s.
-La camara... ¬øporque no puedo girar la camara?, desde luego si se puede no veo la opcion por ningun lado... pero hay ocasiones en las que tienes un obstaculo delante o un arbol o un muro y solo ves la silueta del personaje, pero no ves si hay objetos detras, resulta un poco incomodo; tal vez sea parte del encanto del juego, pero hubiera ido bien eso.
-El mapa... solamente veo el minimapa, pero ningun mapa grande que te indique lo que has explorado de cada nivel, eso ayudaria muchisimo a no tirarte la mitad del tiempo dando vueltas, aunque no es facil perderse, no seria mala idea que pusieran un mapa completo por algun lado.
-No poder moverte libremente por los niveles que has superado es una pena, deberian poder dejar que te desplazaras desde un mundo a otro si te has dejado algo sin resolver o sin ver en otro. La opcion de tirarte al vacio para volver al anterior esta bien, pero deberian hacerlo algo mas comodo desde el mapa de mundos/niveles principal.
-Podrian indicar por algun lado lo que ganas al subir de nivel, lo unico visible que tienes es la mejora de arma que consigues de cuando en cuando (pero no se ve exactamente si tienes mas vida o si de entrada pegas algo mas al subir).
-Los pergaminos magicos son casi ilimitados (aunque se agradece la diversion que aportan al juego), alguno resulta muy absurdo (si habeis jugado al juego y os han regalado el nivel 15 sabreis a lo que me refiero :P); aunque puedes superar la mayor parte del juego sin usarlos.
-A veces tras usar algun pergamino te quedas bloqueado dentro de un muro o obstaculo y tienes que usar la opcion de teletransportarte al principio del nivel (que menos mal que esta ah√≠). Tambien me ha pasado alguna vez que jake o rolftas se queden atras atascados unos segundos atras hasta que se teleportan a tu lado de vuelta.
-Hay ocasiones en que puedes terminar un nivel sin matar una criatura simplemente corriendo directamente hasta la salida del nivel; solo algunos niveles requieren que busques algo para poder terminarlo.
-El valor de repiticion de este juego es el que tu le quieras dar, la siguente partida seguramente sera lo mismo, los logros puedes sacarlos en la primera partida, y los mapas no parece que se hallan generado aleatoriamente... 

A pesar de lo dicho tengo que decir que es un gran juego, si eres fan de la serie, grande o peque√±o, o tu hijo/nieto/sobrino/vecino/etc quiere jugar un buen rato con sus personajes favoritos, no tiene desperdicio, para reirse un rato y echar la tarde desde luego cumple muy bien; si eres un se√±or gamer de apetitos refinados, igual echas en falta muchas cosas; pero si no es asi, yo te recomiendo darle un tiento.

Si tubiera que darle nota al juego le daba sin duda un 7 de 10, me encanta como han clavado muchas cosas de la serie, lo he encontrado en general entretenido y sencillo, se han dejado algunas cosas que para mi gusto hubieran hecho este juego mas perfecto aun, pero para mi esta claro: es un juego destinado a un publico muy joven, hay que entender que seguramente este p√∫blico valore mucho mejor el juego, y que se adapte mejor a ellos; y la verdad que para lo que cuesta cumple de sobra.

review: This game sucked!! I am a huge fan of adventure time and was excited to play this game. The graphics are so BAD, even on the highest setting. There are a ton of glitches. Your shield doesn't protect you at all, and you are much slower than most monsters, meaning you die ALOT, even on the normal mode. The whole games story line isn't really explained well, which was disappointing seeing as it is based off of a TV show that typically has a hilarious one. The map is hard to read and also glitches often, telling you there are places to walk where there aren't any, so you can't rely on it at all. Each new map is an island, meaning you are surrounded by open ground all around you, and if you fall off, which the game will make you do if you even get CLOSE to the edge, you are sent back to the previous level. Then you have to walk you're extrodinarily slow character back to where you were. Combine that with many of the coins you need being close to the edge and you have an annoying headache. Lastly, the color was horrific. It gave me a headache to watch it within half an hour. I've honestly never been so dissappointed by a game I've purchased on Steam before. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. IT IS A PATHETIC SCAR ON A WONDERFUL TV SHOW. Save your money, and your eyes, and move on to something better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000045836', 'num_games_owned': 288, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1397537590}
review:
This game is so close to being really good, but a couple of really irritating (and easily fixable) problems stop me from recommending it. 
Firstly, there's too much repetition, especially with the levels being as big as they are. Moving through a level facing the same enemies over and over wouldn't be too bad if the levels were smaller, but they can be huge and chock full of bad guys, which makes taking them out really tiresome. Plus, with the levels being as big as they are it's easy to get lost, and the minimap just doesn't cut it without a zoom feature.
Another issue is the poorly implemented Enchiridion system. There's not much point limiting the amount of page slots you get if most of the pages are pretty much useless anyway. Only a few of them are actually worth using more than once. This combined with the fact that activating a page often removes your ability to attack, forcing you to run around in circles aimlessly until it wears off, make it an upgrade system that doesn't feel like an upgrade.
Having to go through the previous level again after falling off ledges is ridiculously frustrating. There's no point to it except punishing the player for being careless, which could easily have been accomplished by simply starting the current level again. As it is, it just feels like overkill.
Overall the game isn't bad, but its lack of anything bar killing enemies and collecting pages makes it feel kind of sparse. Maybe if the devs add some extra features/content this would be more satsifying. Having said that, it's definitely not a [i]waste[/i] of 10 dollars, and the only reason I'm giving a not recommended is the fact there's no neutral option.

review:
Its not the worst game of this type; y'know, the kind that sells off the success of the brand. There's plenty of references to the show, at least, and they are integrated with moderate success through the decision to make them affect gameplay rather than just be a collectibale on the side.
The mechanics are, for the most part, bad. A fairly simple combat system with lots of walking in-between. Would have benefitted greatly from a more comprehensive map possibly accessible from the pause menu. All the collecting is meaningless; money and silver keys only get you enchiridion pages which are already in abundance and the combat is, again, so simple that the pages aren't really all that useful.
There's been a lot of fuss over how much support the devs have shown after release. Well, cool your boots; its been like four days since release and, frankly, the game is so riddled with bugs it shouldn't have been released so prematurely. This is all the more embarrassing when you consider its a re-release of an, otherwise, free game. 
All in all, the reasonable pricetag makes up for a lot of its shortcomings, and, for the fans, being able to interact with the Adventure Time universe outside of the show is great. But, ultimately, its not as good as the show, or other videogames, so maybe consider investing your time in those instead.

Visually mathematical and audibily algebraic, whether you're five or thirty-five, by the power of Glob, you'll be slamacow'ing across the Land of Ooo for hours on end.
Original voice cast (Jake, Finn, BMO) provide their talents in game and commentary/instruction. Plenty of seasonal referrences.
Would only really recommend to die hard fans.

Let first open this review off with this. Whilst I do ultimately recommend this game I feel it has plenty of issues which I'll go into.

This game was so close to being this generations 'Toejam & Earl' so very close. For those of you that don't know Toejam & Earl is a game that came out on the sega genesis/megadrive way way back in 1990... or around about then. Regardless it went on to become one of my favourite games of all time and was a favorite between me and my friends when we fancied some co-op action.

So when I found out this game was clearly inspired by Toejam & Earl I was over the moon and very excited. So much so that it coloured my early judgement of the game quite heavily and made me have more positive thoughts at the time than I perhaps should've.

So Finn & Jake's Epic Quest is game where Finn and Jake go around a world (broken up into 6 levles + a boss battle) looking for the portal to the next one. In order to progress though some maps have artifacts (ship pieces for those familiar with Toejam & Earl) which must also be found along with the portal in order to progress. Other similarities to ToeJam & Earl include power ups which are a complete mystery until used which can (more often than not) give a benefit or (unfourtenetly rarely) a disadvantage... this includes the elusive Radomizer which made Toejam & Earl such an unforgiving game.

Which is my first problem with this game... it's not nearly difficult enough. In Toejam & Earl the predictable nature of the enermies was completely forgivable because every last one of them was a genuine threat but in this game the enermies become moslty a means to grind out levels. All of them are completely avoidable and aren't particuarly fun to fight in large number and whilst the combat isn't bad, it feels okay and in groups can be mildly challenging, it becomes pretty tedious with only one apparent combo being present in the game 3 hours and 4 worlds in. Therefore the enermies become a meaningless obstacle which are just there for coin. Which is another issue... you never 'need' money... another thing about Toejam & Earl is money was scarce and it'd cost way more than you'd ever aquire to get everything you'd want on a single map. Here the enermies are easy enough to vanquish without the aid of powerups with the powerups only speeding up the time it takes to kill things and are only every needed when you need to fly or float to specific areas.... the powerups are fun though and the is a lot of variety on offer. But asides from the Randomizer and 'Knife Storm' I saw no powerups which reminded me of 'Total Bummer' or 'Rocket Skates' on Toejam & Earl... in other words just go nuts and dont worry about any ill effects you'll be able to get them all identified again anyways because it's so cheap to do so.

Also the is no co-op, this is a galreing omission from a game thats inspired by a game that is known for it's innovative co-op mode where players where able to individually explore other areas of map but other stages entirely... the tag system from toejam & earl is here but no co-op.

But on it's own merits it's still a decent game for the price, it looks good enough, the gameplay provides a nice distraction in small bursts and you get quite a lot for your money. (I reckon 5hours if you try to complete everything and level up your character) and it's a solid homage to one of my favorite games of all time. It's not bad for a licenced game and is worth the asking price but those looking for a true spiritual succesor to Toejam & Earl this isn't it. It's so close to being a very nice modernized version of it but it falls short of truely capturing what the game great and instead is just a fairly enjoyable romp for a small fee.

review:
First off let me state I will change the recommendation if they fix this game but as it stands right now it is more broken than Goat Simulator (which was at least the goal of that game).

The hit detection is lacking, the mobs seem to ignore a lot of hits and for what ever reason I get hit by projectiles that are no where near me or Jake.  It also seems Jake can be hit when not being used which is just a detriment to the party and reminds me of Minnie from the Mickey and Minnie game where if she dies you die.

Also I recommand right now avoiding the Tree Witch as her greatest power is locking the whole game up.  She has an attack in which she sits on you (makes sense she does it to Jake in the show) and you have to quick time out.  Except sometimes she does the attack and the game just locks.  Oh you can see the mobs moving around and you can even quit to title but for whatever reason the quick time event doesn't load and you are just screwed.  This has happened to me now 4 times forcing me to lose all progress and restart the entire level.

As for the game it's Toe Jam and Earl.  You are two aliens; searching for space parts. On levels that have holes that you can fall down to get to the previous level.  Gathering presents that you do not know what they do until you use them.  Looking for elevators to get you to the next level.  Replace aliens with Finn and Jake.  Replace space parts with game artifacts.  Replace presents with spells.  Replace elevators with portals.  Now you have Fine and Jake's Epic Quest.

You would think this would bother me but frankly Toe Jam and Earl was a great game and if you aren't going to come up with your own good game at least rip one off.

As I said at the start if you can ignore the bugs and have been looking for a Toe Jam and Earl game skinned as Finn and Jake then I recommend this game.  But until the bugs are fix I can't recommand this game right now.

review:
Epic Quest is [b]extremely[/b] reminiscent of ToeJam & Earl. Not a bad thing [b]at all[/b]. 
Performance is good, controls are tight and has support for 1440p+/120hz/60fps+.

Voiceover work has been done by the original cast. Plenty of new lines have been voiced which tie into the 'video game' world very well which is important. Most of your favourite characters from the series make appearances, both the friends and foes. Set across the different worlds each containing at least 5 levels, you will come across a bunch of familiar collectables while following your main 'quest' to obtain the relics. 

Upbeat chiptune 8/16bit styled soundtrack. Not only fits the theme but is rather catchy too.

Great game for the price and fans of the series. 
Easily recommended from what i've played. :)
